Which of the following correctly matches the cell type with its primary function?,Leydig cells ‚Üí sperm maturation,Sertoli cells ‚Üí testosterone production,Granulosa cells ‚Üí estrogen synthesis,Theca cells ‚Üí ovulation trigger,3,"The gonads contain specialized supporting cells that regulate gametogenesis and hormone production, controlled by pituitary gonadotropins (LH, FSH).

column3: Males:

Leydig cells (interstitial): Stimulated by LH ‚Üí produce testosterone, which diffuses into seminiferous tubules. Testosterone is essential for spermatogenesis and development of secondary sex characteristics.

Sertoli cells (within seminiferous tubules): Stimulated by FSH ‚Üí support developing sperm, form the blood-testis barrier, secrete androgen-binding protein, and release inhibin B to provide negative feedback on FSH. They also produce anti-M√ºllerian hormone (AMH) during development.
Females:
Granulosa cells: Stimulated by FSH ‚Üí convert androgens (from theca cells) into estrogens via aromatase. They nurture oocytes and form part of the follicle.
Theca cells: Stimulated by LH ‚Üí produce androgens and progesterone, important for ovulation and corpus luteum function.

column1: Clinical correlations:

column3: Leydig cell tumors ‚Üí testosterone excess ‚Üí precocious puberty in boys.
Sertoli cell tumors ‚Üí rare, can cause feminization.
Granulosa cell tumors ‚Üí estrogen excess ‚Üí abnormal uterine bleeding.

column1: üëâ High-yield review:

column3: Leydig ‚Üí LH ‚Üí Testosterone.
Sertoli ‚Üí FSH ‚Üí Support sperm, Inhibin B, AMH.
Granulosa ‚Üí FSH ‚Üí Estrogen (aromatase).
Theca ‚Üí LH ‚Üí Progesterone/Androgens.

Where are sperm cells produced and where are they stored before ejaculation?,Produced in epididymis; stored in seminal vesicles,Produced in seminiferous tubules; stored in epididymis,Produced in vas deferens; stored in prostate gland,Produced in rete testis; stored in urethra,2,Spermatogenesis occurs in the seminiferous tubules beginning at puberty. Germ cells progress from spermatogonia ‚Üí spermatocytes ‚Üí spermatids ‚Üí spermatozoa, all supported by Sertoli cells and dependent on both FSH and testosterone.

column3: Maturation & storage: Completed spermatozoa are transported to the epididymis, where they mature, gain motility, and are stored until ejaculation.
Transport during ejaculation: Pathway = epididymis ‚Üí vas deferens ‚Üí ejaculatory duct ‚Üí urethra.
Accessory glands:
Seminal vesicles: Contribute majority of seminal volume (fructose, prostaglandins).
Prostate: Adds citrate, PSA, and enzymes.
Bulbourethral glands: Secrete lubricating mucus.

column1: Clinical tie-in: Blockage or absence of vas deferens (e.g., in cystic fibrosis) causes infertility despite normal spermatogenesis.
üëâ High-yield review:

column3: Production = seminiferous tubules.
Maturation/storage = epididymis.
Vas deferens ‚Üí transport.
Accessory glands ‚Üí fluid contributions.",6,,

column1: Which of the following is secreted by chief cells of the stomach?,Intrinsic factor,Hydrochloric acid (HCl),Pepsinogen,Mucus,3,"The stomach mucosa has distinct secretory cells:

column3: Chief cells (fundus/body): Secrete pepsinogen, activated to pepsin in acidic pH. Function = protein digestion.

Parietal cells (fundus/body): Secrete HCl (lowers gastric pH for enzyme activation, antimicrobial action) and intrinsic factor (required for vitamin B12 absorption in ileum). Stimulated by histamine (H2), acetylcholine (M3), and gastrin (CCK-B).
Mucous cells: Secrete mucus + bicarbonate ‚Üí protect epithelium.
G cells (antrum): Secrete gastrin, stimulating parietal cells and gastric motility.

column1: Clinical tie-in:

column3: Pernicious anemia: Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells ‚Üí loss of intrinsic factor ‚Üí B12 deficiency.
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome: Gastrinoma ‚Üí excess gastrin ‚Üí ulcers.
NSAID damage: Impairs mucosal protection ‚Üí ulcers.

column1: üëâ High-yield review:

column3: Chief ‚Üí pepsinogen.
Parietal ‚Üí HCl + IF.
Mucous ‚Üí mucus + HCO‚ÇÉ‚Åª.
G cells ‚Üí gastrin.

All of the following amino acids are ketogenic EXCEPT:,Lysine,Leucine,Isoleucine,Glycine,4,Amino acids are classified by their metabolic fates:

column3: Ketogenic only: Lysine & Leucine. ‚Üí broken down into acetyl-CoA or acetoacetate for ketone body synthesis.
Both ketogenic & glucogenic: Isoleucine, phenylalanine, tryptophan, tyrosine.
Glucogenic only: Most others, including glycine (converted into pyruvate or TCA intermediates).

column1: Exam trick: Glycine is not ketogenic ‚Äî it is purely glucogenic, so it cannot generate ketone bodies.
üëâ High-yield review:

column3: Ketogenic only = Lysine, Leucine.
Both = ‚ÄúPITT‚Äù (Phenylalanine, Isoleucine, Tryptophan, Tyrosine).
Glycine = glucogenic only.

Which enzyme restores oxaloacetate in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle?,Succinate dehydrogenase,Fumarase,Malate dehydrogenase,Citrate synthase,3,The TCA cycle regenerates oxaloacetate (OAA) at the final step, enabling continuation of the cycle.

column3: Malate dehydrogenase: Catalyzes malate ‚Üí OAA, producing NADH. This step is energetically unfavorable but driven forward by rapid OAA consumption in citrate synthase reaction.
Other enzymes in the cycle:
Succinate dehydrogenase: Succinate ‚Üí fumarate (FADH‚ÇÇ produced).
Fumarase: Fumarate ‚Üí malate.
Citrate synthase: OAA + acetyl-CoA ‚Üí citrate (first step).

column1: Clinical tie-in:

column3: TCA cycle defects are rare but secondary deficiencies (e.g., thiamine deficiency ‚Üí Œ±-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase dysfunction) can cause neurologic problems.
Malate shuttle is also important for transferring NADH equivalents into mitochondria.

column1: üëâ High-yield review:

column3: Final enzyme = malate dehydrogenase.
Reaction = malate ‚Üí OAA + NADH.
OAA is essential to accept acetyl-CoA and restart the cycle.",6,,

column1: In gluconeogenesis, biotin acts as a cofactor for which enzyme?,Pyruvate carboxylase,Pyruvate kinase,Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK),Glucose-6-phosphatase,1,"Biotin (vitamin B7) is an essential coenzyme for carboxylation reactions, meaning it carries activated CO‚ÇÇ to help form new carbon‚Äìcarbon bonds. The classic high-yield fact: all carboxylases require biotin.

In gluconeogenesis, the key biotin-dependent enzyme is pyruvate carboxylase, located in the mitochondria. It catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate (3C) ‚Üí oxaloacetate (OAA, 4C), using CO‚ÇÇ, ATP, and biotin as cofactors. This is the first bypass step of gluconeogenesis, allowing the body to generate glucose from non-carbohydrate sources during fasting.

column3: PEPCK (phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase): Converts OAA ‚Üí PEP, but requires GTP, not biotin.
Pyruvate kinase: Functions in glycolysis (PEP ‚Üí pyruvate), not gluconeogenesis.
Glucose-6-phosphatase: Final gluconeogenic enzyme, releasing free glucose into the blood.

column1: Clinical tie-in: Biotin deficiency (rare, can occur with excessive raw egg white ingestion due to avidin) can impair gluconeogenesis, leading to hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, dermatitis, and alopecia.
üëâ High-yield summary:

column3: Biotin = all carboxylases.
Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate ‚Üí OAA (gluconeogenesis bypass).
PEPCK: OAA ‚Üí PEP (uses GTP, not biotin).
Other enzymes listed are not biotin dependent.",6,,

column1: Which metabolic pathway is the major source of NADPH in cells?,TCA cycle,Pentose phosphate pathway,Glycolysis,Beta-oxidation of fatty acids,2,"The Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), also called the hexose monophosphate shunt, is an alternative glucose metabolism pathway that branches from glycolysis at glucose-6-phosphate. It operates in the cytosol and has two major products:
‚Ä¢        NADPH, a crucial reducing agent used in:
‚Ä¢ Reductive biosynthesis (fatty acid, cholesterol, steroid synthesis).
‚Ä¢ Maintaining reduced glutathione in red blood cells, which protects against oxidative damage from reactive oxygen species. This is why G6PD deficiency leads to hemolysis.
‚Ä¢ Cytochrome P450 hydroxylation reactions, important for detoxification in the liver.
‚Ä¢        Ribose-5-phosphate, essential for nucleotide and nucleic acid synthesis.
By contrast:
‚Ä¢        Glycolysis and the TCA cycle produce NADH, which is used in oxidative phosphorylation to generate ATP.
‚Ä¢        Œ≤-oxidation of fatty acids produces NADH and FADH2, feeding into the electron transport chain for energy, but not NADPH.
üëâ High-yield summary: PPP is the only pathway that generates NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate; glycolysis/TCA/Œ≤-oxidation generate NADH/FADH2 for ATP, not NADPH.",6,,

Which structural feature distinguishes thymine from uracil?,A hydroxyl group at carbon 2,A methyl group at carbon 5,An amino group at carbon 4,A double bond at carbon 6,2,"Both uracil and thymine are pyrimidine bases. Uracil is found only in RNA, while thymine is found only in DNA. They are structurally identical except that thymine has a methyl group at the 5‚Ä≤ carbon, while uracil does not. This methylation helps stabilize DNA and allows repair enzymes to distinguish thymine from uracil that may arise via cytosine deamination. The other options are incorrect: hydroxyl at carbon 2 is a ribose feature, not a pyrimidine modification; both uracil and thymine share the same carbonyl at C4; and the double bond positions are common to both.",6,,

Which of the following best describes the role of gamma motor neurons in skeletal muscle physiology?,They innervate extrafusal fibers to generate force during contraction.,They regulate intrafusal muscle spindle sensitivity to stretch.,They mediate inhibition of antagonist muscles through reciprocal innervation.,They activate Golgi tendon organs to sense tension.,2,"Skeletal muscle fibers are divided into extrafusal fibers, which generate force, and intrafusal fibers, which are housed in muscle spindles and detect stretch. Gamma motor neurons innervate intrafusal fibers and adjust their baseline tension, setting the gain of the stretch reflex. This ensures spindles remain sensitive even when the muscle shortens, allowing regulation of muscle tone and length. In contrast, alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal fibers to produce force. Reciprocal innervation involves inhibitory interneurons mediated via Ia afferents, not gamma motor neurons. Golgi tendon organs sense tension and are not activated by gamma motor neurons.
üëâ High-yield review:
‚Ä¢ Gamma motor neurons ‚Üí intrafusal fibers (spindle sensitivity).
‚Ä¢ Alpha motor neurons ‚Üí extrafusal fibers (force generation).
‚Ä¢ Reciprocal inhibition ‚Üí Ia afferents and interneurons.
‚Ä¢ Golgi tendon organs ‚Üí sense tension, protective reflex.",6,,

Which of the following best describes the effect of pulmonary fibrosis on lung compliance?,Increased compliance,Decreased compliance,No change in compliance,Increased compliance due to airway obstruction,2,"Lung compliance is defined as the change in lung volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure, representing how easily the lung tissue can expand. In pulmonary fibrosis, excessive deposition of collagen and connective tissue in the interstitium makes the lungs stiff and difficult to inflate, leading to reduced compliance. At the cellular level, type I pneumocytes cover most of the alveolar surface and provide the thin barrier for gas exchange, while type II pneumocytes produce surfactant, which normally reduces surface tension and helps maintain compliance. In fibrosis, even with surfactant, the rigidity of scarred tissue prevents normal expansion. High-yield facts: Compliance increases in emphysema and decreases in fibrosis. Compliance is proportional to distensibility and inversely related to elasticity.",6,,

Which hormone stimulates pancreatic bicarbonate secretion?,Gastrin,Secretin,Cholecystokinin (CCK),Somatostatin,2,"Secretin is released by S cells of the duodenum and proximal jejunum in response to acidic chyme entering from the stomach. Its primary action is to stimulate the pancreatic ductal cells to secrete bicarbonate-rich fluid, which neutralizes gastric acid and provides an optimal pH for pancreatic enzyme activity. This bicarbonate secretion protects the duodenal mucosa and ensures that enzymes like pancreatic lipase and amylase can function. Secretin also suppresses gastric acid secretion and slows gastric emptying, coordinating digestion between the stomach and intestine. High-yield facts: Secretin is known as the bicarbonate hormone, released by S cells, stimulated by acid, increases pancreatic bicarbonate, and decreases gastric acid.",6,,

In which structure do sperm undergo maturation and acquire motility after being produced in the testes?,Seminiferous tubules,Vas deferens,Epididymis,Prostate,3,"Sperm are produced in the seminiferous tubules of the testes under the influence of Sertoli and Leydig cells. However, newly formed sperm are non-motile and incapable of fertilization. They travel to the epididymis, where they mature, acquire motility, and are stored until ejaculation. During ejaculation, sperm pass through the vas deferens, mix with fluids from the seminal vesicles and prostate, and form semen. High-yield facts: Production occurs in seminiferous tubules, maturation and storage occur in the epididymis, and sperm are transported by the vas deferens during ejaculation.",6,,

What reaction is catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase in glycolysis?,Conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate,"Conversion of 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to 3-phosphoglycerate with ATP formation",Conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to fructose-6-phosphate,Conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate,2,"Phosphoglycerate kinase catalyzes the first substrate-level phosphorylation in glycolysis, where a phosphate group from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (1,3-BPG) is transferred to ADP, forming ATP and 3-phosphoglycerate. This reaction is reversible and also functions in gluconeogenesis, where ATP is consumed. Because this is one of the ATP-generating steps in glycolysis, it is critical for anaerobic metabolism.
üëâ High-yield notes:
- Net ATP of glycolysis: 2 ATP per glucose.
- Substrate-level phosphorylation requires no mitochondria.
- In RBCs, 1,3-BPG can be diverted to 2,3-BPG, which regulates hemoglobin oxygen affinity.",6,,

During prolonged fasting, all of the following pathways are active EXCEPT:,Glycogenolysis,Gluconeogenesis,Lipolysis,Glycogenesis,4,"In the fasting state, the body maintains glucose via glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, while lipolysis mobilizes fatty acids for ketone production. Glycogenesis, however, occurs only in the fed state under insulin and is inactive during fasting.
üëâ High-yield notes:
- Hormones: fasting ‚Üí ‚Üë glucagon, ‚Üë epinephrine, ‚Üì insulin.
- Glycogenolysis dominates first 24 hrs; gluconeogenesis dominates later.
- Ketogenesis increases after 2‚Äì3 days for brain and muscle energy.",6,,

A patient with pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency would have impaired synthesis of which molecule?,Acetyl-CoA,Lactate,Oxaloacetate,Alanine,1,"The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, feeding the TCA cycle. Deficiency prevents acetyl-CoA production, leading to shunting of pyruvate into lactate (lactic acidosis) and alanine. It requires cofactors: Thiamine (B1), Lipoic acid, CoA (B5), FAD (B2), NAD+ (B3).
üëâ High-yield notes:
- Presents with neurodevelopmental delay, seizures, lactic acidosis.
- Inhibited by arsenic (binds lipoic acid).
- Treatment: ketogenic diet to bypass glycolysis and supply acetyl-CoA via fat metabolism.",6,,

In glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, patients cannot produce enough of which molecule, leading to hemolysis?,ATP,NADH,NADPH,FADH2,3,"G6PD catalyzes the first step of the pentose phosphate pathway, producing NADPH. NADPH maintains reduced glutathione in RBCs, preventing oxidative damage. Deficiency (X-linked) causes RBCs to be vulnerable to oxidative stress (fava beans, sulfa drugs, infections), resulting in hemolysis. Findings: Heinz bodies (denatured Hb) and bite cells.
üëâ High-yield notes:
- PPP occurs in cytoplasm (RBCs, liver, adrenal cortex).
- NADPH also used for fatty acid synthesis and respiratory burst.
- Hemolytic crises are triggered by oxidative stress.",6,,

Here are two statements about nitrogen metabolism:

Statement 1: Glutamine synthetase incorporates ammonia into glutamate to form glutamine, which serves as a nontoxic transporter of ammonia in the blood.
Statement 2: Ornithine acts as an intermediate in the urea cycle, which has two mitochondrial and three cytosolic steps, occurring mainly in the liver.

Which of the following is true?,Statement 1 only,Statements 1 and 2,Statement 2 only,None,2,"Both statements are correct: Glutamine synthetase incorporates free ammonia into glutamate to form glutamine, which detoxifies ammonia and allows safe nitrogen transport in the blood. Glutamine can deliver nitrogen to tissues for biosynthetic pathways or to the liver/kidney for processing. Ornithine is a crucial intermediate in the urea cycle, the main nitrogen excretion pathway. The cycle has five steps: two mitochondrial (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, ornithine transcarbamylase) and three cytosolic (argininosuccinate synthetase, argininosuccinate lyase, arginase). Ornithine accepts carbamoyl phosphate in mitochondria to form citrulline, enabling nitrogen disposal as urea. High-yield points: Glutamine synthetase = glutamate + NH‚ÇÉ ‚Üí glutamine (detox + nitrogen transport). Glutamine = safe ammonia carrier. Ornithine = intermediate in urea cycle. Urea cycle = 2 mitochondrial, 3 cytosolic steps. Main site: liver, minor in kidney.",6,,

Esophageal varices most likely result in which clinical presentation?,Dysphagia,Hematemesis,Hoarseness,Melena,2,"Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus due to portal hypertension (commonly cirrhosis). Pathophysiology: left gastric vein (portal) anastomoses with the azygos vein (systemic). Elevated portal pressure dilates these collaterals. Fragile varices rupture ‚Üí massive hematemesis, often fatal. Other shunts: paraumbilical veins ‚Üí caput medusae; superior rectal veins ‚Üí hemorrhoids.

High-yield points:
  • Portal HTN ‚Üí left gastric ‚Üî azygos
  • Hematemesis = hallmark
  • Other stigmata: hemorrhoids, caput medusae
  • Life-threatening in cirrhosis
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Dysphagia: strictures, tumors, achalasia
  • Hoarseness: recurrent laryngeal nerve (CN X) injury in thyroid or lung disease
  • Melena: black tarry stool; possible but not primary in varices
",6,,

Which of the following produces a positive chronotropic effect on the heart?,Clipping the vagus nerve,Administration of a beta-blocker,Activation of parasympathetic fibers,Increased acetylcholine release at the SA node,1,"Chronotropism = effect on heart rate. Positive chronotropy = increased HR. Negative chronotropy = decreased HR. The vagus nerve (CN X) provides parasympathetic input to the SA node, slowing HR via acetylcholine at M2 receptors. Clipping the vagus nerve removes parasympathetic influence ‚Üí unopposed sympathetic stimulation ‚Üí ‚Üë SA node firing ‚Üí tachycardia.

High-yield points:
  • Vagus = parasympathetic brake
  • Cut vagus = ‚Üë HR
  • Sympathetic Œ≤1 = positive chronotropy
  • Parasympathetic (ACh/M2) = negative chronotropy
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Beta-blockers: block Œ≤1 ‚Üí ‚Üì HR (negative chronotropy)
  • Parasympathetic activation: slows HR
  • Acetylcholine at SA node: M2 receptor ‚Üí ‚Üì HR
",6,,

Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause edema formation?,Hypoalbuminemia,Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure,Increased vascular permeability,Elevated plasma albumin concentration,4,"Edema results from imbalance in Starling forces. Increased hydrostatic pressure (e.g., heart failure), decreased oncotic pressure (e.g., hypoalbuminemia), and increased vascular permeability (inflammation) all promote fluid leakage. Elevated plasma albumin raises oncotic pressure, drawing fluid into capillaries, opposing edema.

High-yield points:
  • Hydrostatic ‚Üë ‚Üí edema
  • Oncotic ‚Üì (low albumin) ‚Üí edema
  • Permeability ‚Üë ‚Üí edema
  • High albumin ‚Üí resists edema
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Hypoalbuminemia: lowers oncotic pressure ‚Üí edema
  • Hydrostatic ‚Üë: venous congestion ‚Üí edema
  • Permeability ‚Üë: inflammation ‚Üí edema
",6,,

Which of the following should normally not be found in urine?,Urea,Creatinine,Sodium,Albumin,4,"Normal urine contains urea, creatinine, electrolytes, and water. Albumin is normally excluded by the glomerular filtration barrier. Albuminuria indicates glomerular damage, as in diabetic nephropathy.

High-yield points:
  • Normal urine: urea, creatinine, electrolytes
  • Albuminuria = renal pathology
  • Proteinuria = hallmark of kidney disease
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Urea: normal waste
  • Creatinine: normal muscle breakdown product
  • Sodium: normal electrolyte
",6,,

Shock causes all of the following except:,Hypotension,Reduced tissue perfusion,GI bleeding,Lactic acidosis,3,"Shock = systemic hypoperfusion due to low cardiac output or effective circulating volume. It leads to hypotension, reduced tissue perfusion, and lactic acidosis from anaerobic metabolism. GI bleeding is not a direct feature of shock, though ischemia can predispose.

High-yield points:
  • Shock = hypoperfusion
  • Hypotension = hallmark
  • Lactic acidosis = anaerobic metabolism
  • GI bleeding = not classic
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Hypotension: defining feature
  • Reduced perfusion: definition of shock
  • Lactic acidosis: hallmark metabolic change
",6,,

Which of the following best describes the action of glucagon?,Stimulates glycogen synthesis,Stimulates glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis,Stimulates lipogenesis,Inhibits gluconeogenesis,2,"Glucagon, secreted by pancreatic Œ±-cells, maintains blood glucose during fasting. It stimulates glycogenolysis (breakdown of glycogen) and gluconeogenesis (new glucose production). Also promotes lipolysis in adipose tissue. Acts mainly on the liver.

High-yield points:
  • Glucagon = fasting hormone
  • ‚Üë Glycogenolysis + ‚Üë Gluconeogenesis
  • ‚Üë Lipolysis
  • Opposes insulin
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Glycogen synthesis: insulin effect
  • Lipogenesis: insulin-mediated
  • Inhibits gluconeogenesis: opposite of glucagon
",6,,

Which of the following correctly matches adrenergic receptor type with its primary physiologic effect?,Œ±1 receptor ‚Üí smooth muscle contraction,Œ±2 receptor ‚Üí inhibit norepinephrine and insulin release,Œ≤1 receptor ‚Üí increase cardiac output and heart rate,all of the above,4,"Adrenergic receptors mediate sympathetic effects:

Œ±1 receptors: Gq ‚Üí ‚Üë IP3/DAG ‚Üí smooth muscle contraction (vasoconstriction, ‚Üë BP, mydriasis).
Œ±2 receptors: Gi ‚Üí ‚Üì cAMP ‚Üí inhibit norepinephrine release + inhibit insulin secretion.
Œ≤1 receptors: Gs ‚Üí ‚Üë cAMP ‚Üí increase HR, contractility, renin release.
Œ≤2 receptors: Gs ‚Üí ‚Üë cAMP ‚Üí smooth muscle relaxation (bronchodilation, vasodilation) + ‚Üë glucose output.

High-yield points:
  • Œ±1 = vasoconstriction, ‚Üë BP
  • Œ±2 = ‚Üì NE + ‚Üì insulin
  • Œ≤1 = ‚Üë HR, contractility, renin
  • Œ≤2 = bronchodilation, vasodilation, ‚Üë glucose
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Each listed effect is correct ‚Üí best answer is 'All of the above'
",6,,

What is the renal clearance rate of glucose under normal physiologic conditions?,0 mL/min,60 mL/min,125 mL/min,600 mL/min,1,"Glucose clearance is normally 0 mL/min because filtered glucose is completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubule by sodium-glucose transporters (SGLT2, SGLT1). No glucose is excreted under physiologic conditions. Glucosuria appears when plasma glucose exceeds the transport maximum (Tm ~375 mg/min), correlating with a renal threshold of ~180‚Äì200 mg/dL. SGLT2 inhibitors increase urinary glucose clearance intentionally.

High-yield points:
  • Glucose clearance = ~0 mL/min normally
  • Reabsorbed in proximal tubule by SGLTs
  • Threshold ~180‚Äì200 mg/dL ‚Üí glucosuria
  • SGLT2 inhibitors ‚Üë clearance
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • 60 mL/min: too high
  • 125 mL/min: equals GFR, for solutes like inulin
  • 600 mL/min: renal plasma flow, not glucose clearance
",6,,

Which of the following is not a function of the sympathetic nervous system?,Increase heart rate,Bronchodilation,Pupil constriction,Decrease GI motility,3,"The sympathetic system mediates 'fight-or-flight' responses via adrenergic receptors. Œ≤1 receptors ‚Üë HR and contractility; Œ≤2 causes bronchodilation and vasodilation; Œ±1 causes vasoconstriction and piloerection; overall, sympathetic tone decreases GI motility. In the iris, sympathetic Œ±1 stimulates the radial muscle to cause mydriasis (pupil dilation). Pupil constriction (miosis) is parasympathetic via CN III and the sphincter pupillae.

High-yield points:
  • Sympathetic: ‚Üë HR, ‚Üë BP, bronchodilation, ‚Üì GI
  • Mydriasis = sympathetic (Œ±1)
  • Miosis = parasympathetic (CN III, M3)
  • Sweat glands = sympathetic cholinergic exception
Why the other options are incorrect:
  • Increase HR: Œ≤1-mediated
  • Bronchodilation: Œ≤2-mediated
  • Decrease GI motility: sympathetic effect
",6,,

Which anterior pituitary hormones are secreted by basophils versus acidophils?,"Basophils secrete FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH; acidophils secrete GH, prolactin","Basophils secrete GH, prolactin; acidophils secrete FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH",Basophils secrete only ACTH; acidophils secrete all others,Acidophils secrete all anterior pituitary hormones,1,"Anterior pituitary cells: Basophils secrete B-FLAT (FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH). Acidophils secrete GPA (GH, prolactin). Mnemonic: B-FLAT, GPA.

High-yield points:
  • Basophils: FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH
  • Acidophils: GH, prolactin
Why incorrect:
  • Option 2: reversed
  • Option 3: incomplete
  • Option 4: false, split between cell types
",6,,

Absence of secretion from which organ is not absolutely essential for survival?,Pancreas,Thyroid gland,Adrenal cortex,Adrenal medulla,4,"The adrenal medulla secretes epinephrine and norepinephrine, important for stress responses but not essential for life. Sympathetic nerves provide redundancy. By contrast, adrenal cortex hormones (cortisol, aldosterone) are essential, as are insulin and thyroid hormones.

High-yield points:
  • Non-essential: adrenal medulla
  • Essential: adrenal cortex, pancreas, thyroid
Why incorrect:
  • Pancreas: insulin vital
  • Thyroid: required for metabolism
  • Adrenal cortex: cortisol/aldosterone needed for survival
",6,,

Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in the collecting duct by upregulating which channel?,Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫ ATPase,ENaC,NKCC2,Aquaporin-2,2,"Aldosterone acts on principal cells of the collecting duct, upregulating luminal ENaC channels and stimulating basolateral Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫ ATPase. This promotes Na‚Å∫ retention, K‚Å∫ secretion, and water reabsorption.

High-yield points:
  • ‚Üë ENaC, ‚Üë Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫ ATPase, ‚Üë K‚Å∫ secretion
  • Stimuli: angiotensin II, hyperkalemia
Why incorrect:
  • Na‚Å∫/K‚Å∫ ATPase: stimulated but not the direct luminal channel
  • NKCC2: loop of Henle
  • Aquaporin-2: regulated by ADH
",6,,

Loss of GABAergic inhibition in the CNS is most associated with which clinical outcome?,Flaccid paralysis,Spastic paralysis with tetany,Hypotension,Hyporeflexia,2,"GABA is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the CNS. Loss of GABA/glycine activity ‚Üí neuronal hyperexcitability ‚Üí spastic paralysis, tetany, hyperreflexia. Seen in tetanus toxin exposure. UMN lesions also cause spastic paralysis.

High-yield points:
  • GABA blocks hyperexcitability
  • Loss ‚Üí tetany, spasticity
Why incorrect:
  • Flaccid paralysis: LMN lesions
  • Hypotension: not main outcome
  • Hyporeflexia: opposite; loss causes hyperreflexia
",6,,

Where is the highest osmolarity in the nephron normally found?,Proximal tubule,Descending loop of Henle,Distal tubule,Collecting duct (medullary),4,"The highest osmolarity is in the inner medullary collecting duct, especially with ADH present. The countercurrent multiplier and vasa recta maintain the medullary gradient (>1200 mOsm).

High-yield points:
  • Highest osmolarity: medullary collecting duct
  • Countercurrent multiplier + ADH are essential
Why incorrect:
  • Proximal: isosmotic reabsorption
